stem: A client with type 1 diabetes presents with fruity-smelling breath, Kussmaul respirations, and a blood glucose of 520 mg/dL. The serum pH is 7.2. Complete the clinical bowtie.

actions.text: Restrict fluids to avoid cerebral edema
Start an intravenous regular insulin protocol

rationale.correct: DKA is caused by absolute insulin deficiency (c1) often triggered by infection (c2). The first actions are hydration with saline (a1) and regular insulin (a2). Monitoring potassium (p1) is critical as it drops during treatment. Anion gap (p2) tracks the resolution of acidosis.
rationale.incorrect: Bicarbonate (a3) is rarely used unless pH is < 6.9. Fluid restriction (a4) is contraindicated; rapid hydration is needed first.

clinicalPearls: Once glucose reaches ~250 mg/dL, add dextrose to the IV fluid to prevent hypoglycemia.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that insulin moves potassium into cells; a 'normal' potassium in DKA is actually low, and it will drop further with treatment.

reviewUnits.heading: DKA Management
reviewUnits.body: DKA is a metabolic crisis requiring careful fluid and electrolyte management.
